Award.AwardTitle: EARS: Collaborative Research: Enhancing Spectral Access via Directional Spectrum Sensing Employing 3D Cone Filterbanks: Interdisciplinary Algorithms and Prototypes

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
NSF Proposal No. 1247940
Dr. A. Madanayake (PI)

Intellectual Merit
This NSF EARS project proposes a new spectrum sensing architecture combined with joint link scheduling and routing to significantly enhance access to the radio spectrum. Traditional non-directional sensing algorithms do not offer information about the direction of primary and secondary signals, directional information on interference, and information on network node location, and hence significantly limit the potential of cognitive radio technology in terms of spectrum utilization. This project envisions a generalized framework leading to the determination and subsequent utilization of spatio-temporal vacancies in time, frequency, position and direction. New mathematical, hardware, and software algorithms and techniques will be pioneered toward enabling low-complexity digital radios. Multi-dimensional sensed information will drive the innovation of cross-layer link scheduling and routing schemes aimed at boosting the cognitive radio network performance. The proposed innovations will be accomplished through mathematical formulation and modeling of directional sensing algorithms based on multi-dimensional signal processing concepts. The project will also investigate low-complexity fast algorithms for enabling real-time realization leading to new types of (i) digital integrated circuits, (ii) new design techniques for cognitive radios, and (iii) highly agile radio frequency component models all leading to an integrated directional spectrum sensor.

Broader Impacts
This proposal entails tightly integrated research and educational activities at four universities including an HBCU and an undergraduate institution. Spectrum-aware education is pursued as one of the key components of the project because wireless system designers and policy makers alike urgently need this knowledge for pioneering new innovations in this upcoming area of technology. Scientific findings enabled by the proposed research in the cognitive radio networks will serve as a tangible tool-box for engineering transformational technologies such technologies could, in turn, lead to mushrooming of businesses and services that directly benefit from intellectual property (e.g. patents). This research will foster startup firms manufacturing new devices that will potentially improve today's wireless infrastructure. Distinct and diverse applications in education, energy, environment, healthcare, infrastructure, and public-safety will be studied from a unified perspective, i.e. spectrum scarcity, with the objective of maximizing the untapped economic potential of such scientific findings. The project will involve minorities, underrepresented groups, and women in research, while inspiring spectrum-aware educational concepts through new laboratory modules. Participation of underrepresented groups and women will be encouraged and promoted through mentorship and outreach, aimed at inspiring them to take up graduate studies in engineering and computer science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Enhancing Access to Radio Spectrum (EARS) project explored the use of multi-dimensional signal processing theory, algorithms and digital circuit implementations for cognitive radio spectrum sensing applications. The ongoing expansion of radio frequency (RF) wireless applications is causing the saturation on available frequency allocations that are decided by the Federal Communications Commission (FCC). Cognitive Radio (CR) attempts to create a ``sharing economy'' for radio spectrum where secondary users can "tap into" licensed spectral bands when the owners of those bands (primary users) are not using them. The ability to accurately know whether or not a radio channel is used by its primary user (or another secondary user) before attempting to dynamically utilize that electromagnetic bandwidth is known as spectrum sensing in the wireless engineering community.

Our EARS project explored this very demanding problem from the standpoint of multi-dimensional systems and signal processing with hardware implementations. In particular, we formulated the concept of a spatio-temporal spectral white space, which allows not only frequency channels, but spatial directions of wave propagation as well, to be considered when a secondary user is deciding the best possible course of action in a spectrum sharing wireless network. By exploiting so-called 2-D/3-D infinite impulse response (IIR) fan/cone filterbanks, which are essentially recursive digital filters that are guaranteed to be stable while operating over several spatial dimensions and the time dimension, the research led to the conclusion that high performance spectrum sensors can be built with significantly lower complexity than conventional approaches that employ ``phased-array'' type radio array receivers. One can obtain low complexity because the recursive multi-dimensional filters offer high-selectivity and wide band operation while being realized in smaller, lower-power electronic circuits. In addition to algorithms, our team explored a rich subset of innovations spanning antenna designs for wideband operation, compact high-performance microwave circuits for spectrum sensor array processors, digital implementations of beamformers, spectrum sensors and Fourier-transform cores, algorithms for detecting the wireless modulation type automatically, and various network layer algorithms that can potentially lead to improved spectrum access in the future.

In addition to multi-dimensional filterbank based beamforming algorithms, microwave circuits and digital systems, this EARS project resulted in three schemes/protocols for cognitive radio networks: 1) a disruption aware routing and link scheduling (DARS) scheme that effectively reduces channel switching and reduces disruption to communication sessions of secondary users in cognitive radio networks; 2) a wavelet based wideband spectrum sensing algorithm that can effectively detects both the existence of primary user signals and the signal edge locations accurately, to identify the unused primary user channels in a wide band; and 3) two MAC protocols for coexisting ad-hoc cognitive radio networks, and for coexisting primary and secondary networks, with the first protocol to achieve fair channel access among coexisting networks, and the second protocol to enable secondary users to transparently co-access spectrum with primary users. The developed schemes and protocols effectively utilize the spectrum opportunities in the temporal, frequency, and spatial domains, to significantly improve the performance of CR networks.  

The project resulted in a multitude of community outreach and educational activities. These include several summer workshops targeting minority as well as economically underpreviledged communities in collaboration with an HBCU, multiple research experience for undergraduates (REU), undergraduate internships, an international summer intern (Brazil) at the University of Akron, multiple special sessions at various IEEE conferences attended by experts from the world over, an invited Keynote address in an IEEE sponsored conference, a field visit at the Greenbank Radio Telescope for undergrad and graduate students, development of related course modules for senior undergrad and graduate courses, regional workshops for teaching advanced digital design using the Reconfigurable Open Architecture Computing Hardware (ROACH) based field-programmable gate array (FPGA) system which is a de facto standard for radio astronomy instrumentation. The project also partially supported several PhD and MS students across the four institutions. The PIs take this oppotunity to deeply thank the National Science Foundation (NSF) EARS program for financial support.

Dr. Arjuna Madanayake (University of Akron), Dr. Sen Xin (Old Dominion University), Dr. Vijay Devabhaktuni (University of Toledo) and Dr. Srinivas Vemuru (Ohio Northern).
